Copy of this letter sent to Moran
August 15, 1940
Senora Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas
207 Calle 17,
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
Permit me to send you herewith a confidential memorandum which I have
written up mostly for my own information. I hope to use this information, at least
part of it, as a background for my address at the Lazear Memorial dedication.
Part of it also will be used in my formal report to the Cuban government, in an
attempt to have them recognize your farm as the true site of Camp Lazear. You will
appreciate, therefore, how anxious I am to have you check over this to be sure that
I am right in my statements. I regret that it is too long for me to have it trans-
lated in Spanish but I am sure that your daughter and Senora Cabrera will be able
to understand it and read it to you, and I will be most appreciative of their wonder-
ful help in this matter. May I ask your particular attention to certain paragraphs,
and as I am anxious to have you correct any mistakes which may appear herein and par-
ticularly to amplify it with any information that you can give me, permit me to make
the following suggestion. I would never ask you to go to the bother of writing a
long, hand-written reply. Would you permit me to ask Mrs. R. Hart Phillips, of
Manzana de Gomez, 533, Havana (the widow of the former Havana correspondent for the
New York Times, who is now doing secretarial work, and who helped me considerably
when I was there before) to call on you at your convenience and take down your
comments and answers in shorthand. She can then write them up, submit a copy for
your final appraisal and then send them to me. I will be more than delighted to pay
whatever charges she makes in order that I may have from you an authorized and signed
statement as to the historical events which took place on your farm, and your identi-
fication of the site of these experiments.

Paragraph 32: Do you or any of your family know the name of some govern-
mental tree expert who could estimate the age of the framboyant tree and the two or
three other trees around the shacks in photograph No. These shacks are near
the quarry behind your house. I am also anxious to have him give me the probable age
of the framboyant tree at the false site already marked by the government.

Par. 53: I am asking Mr. Pogolotti to check this paragraph but would like
to have you do so also. I am anxious to know when he or his brother bought part of your
farm, that part where Camp Lazear was, and I also want to know when he sold the part
now used as a quarry and to whom it was sold. Can you tell me when the quarry was
begun, who now owns the quarry and who is its president? Perhaps they may have some old
photographs of the land before the digging was begun.

Par. 54: Are my directions as to how to reach the San Jose farm correct?
When was the fence (wall) built around your present estate? I have forgotten whether
it is stone or concret.

Par. 55: I hesitate to ask for the exact age of your niece,
Senora Dolores Morales, but considering her important recollections, it is
important for me to know how old she was when Camp Lazear was established. I
would appreciate it greatly if you would read the remarks that I remember she
made to me and if she can amplify them or correct them, I would be grateful.
Do you think her brother would have any worth-while recollections, and do you
think it would be worthwhile for me to write him? You will appreciate that when
I write this up, it will be much more forceful if I can use your remarks in
quotation marks, and I will be most grateful if you will amplify them as extensively
as you can.

Par. 61: What was the date of the old map framed in your parlor,
the first map of the San Jose farm?

Pars. 59 to 67: I am particularly anxious that you check and amplify
these paragraphs as much as you can. Can you tell me why, on the 1907 map,
which you showed me, the name Calzada de Maximo Gomez is given to the street
Calzada Real? What does the name Loma Llavos on the 1917 map indicate?
Did the American army doctors when they abandoned Camp Lazear, leave the wooden floors
from the tents or the wooden floors from the buildings?

Most important of all, will you please draw a circle on maps Nos.
showing where you believe Camp Lazear exactly was, in terms of the present lay of
the land, and will you please check this with my statements in paragraphs 65 and 67?
You will appreciate that if I have a map marked by you in person and preferably with
your signature on the side saying, “This is where Camp Lazear was” and signed “Senora
Rojas” this will be the most important proof I can get regarding the proper identity
of Camp Lazear.

Par. 68: I believe I have already asked you who owns the quarry now
and whether they might have any old photographs of the land. I am going to ask for
Mr. Pogolotti's help on this.

Par. 69: My recollection is that Dr. Beato does not understand English.
I am going to write him a letter and will send Miss Cabrera a copy of it, and I will
be very grateful indeed if between Miss Cabrera and Mrs. Philips, I could receive an
answer from Dr. Beato, as to certain historical aspects mentioned in my memorandum.

Par. 70 and 71: I am most anxious to have your reaction to these paragraphs,
and if you can amplify this in your statement made to Mrs. Phillips for me, I will
appreciate it greatly.

Would you permit me to have a professional photographer visit the San
Jose farm and take a photograph of the lay of the land from the upstairs porch toward
the old site of Camp Lazear? I am very anxious to have such a photograph and through
Mr. Moran will try to make arrangements for this if you will let me do so. Would you
also permit me to buy a limb or a part of a limb of a tree on the San Jose farm?
Perhaps some tree near the site of Camp Lazear, in order that I can have some small
souvenirs made from this limb. Perhaps the tree near the shack that I have mentioned
would be the nearest tree. Did your husband ever own any preoprty near Camp Columbia?
I am afraid that the Cuban authorities may try to say that he did, and that they are still
right in the site that they have chosen.

I cannot tell you how grateful I am for all the courtesies and help that
you have given me so far, and I am sure that you will appreciate the historical signifi-
cance of your farm and be glad to help me in establishing it as the true site of Camp
Lazear. Whatever information you can give me will be indeed appreciated, and if I can
have it at your earliest convenience, I will be most grateful, as the Cuban government
wants my report soon.
